Publications
Acrobat Bit Dance

Poet: Hunter Blu

Taking too long for me to write down my deep deep adult like time shining sorrows

Yearnings, longings, desires and sorrows

Dolores walking down runways against parallel apocalyptic desires

Touch the fire that burns your races liars

open carry,

open carry in front of the White House

carry it all over your shoulder then move forward

Futuristic drama set against backdrop serendeptity pink flowers

Surrender uppity

Pink flowers.

Yes

Purple, blue pink magenta red.

Lips of a holy liar red,

seduced into the bed mattress of another ethereal ghoul mistress

In my dreams alluding the reality of death and sleep

Wrapped in an American flag as I hump fraudulent imaginary dreams

I need more peace

Give me back my dreams

Keep it in me

Keep it in these

Highs

And lows.

Baby girls in drag cursing a endless history of executive dads

Presidential fathers will not stop Lucent homo martyrs

TO FEEL ALIVE

INSIDE

What does this mean when the clock strikes past nine?

First caught in the grams lustful tension between the grip of myself

The grip of myself inside

how scary adult youth is

Cannot take any more flashy pics for my virgin lips

Insta pics, instant tits, blue cell phone screen to the laptop dopamemes,

take it off for me, if you gimme another token ill give you what you need, feed my needs tell me what is it youâ€™re

keeping from me?

Pink flowers sundress sunset dwindling twilight kiss upon my fat brown lips floating down into my modestly luxurious

mattress until the last whisp Er.

Whisper in my ear and I will know you were here I swear

I swear I cannot bear anymore quiet messages under woken sleep that someone else was taken by mother deaths

heavenly far cry weep.

To all Those beautiful , glamorous , unique, wholesome , hot , damned souls.

How does your work connect to the BLM movement or systemic racism?

The strings which attach my work to the systematic racism that politicizes my body are tethered. In my poetry, I often find myself "freestyling" through my hands onto the keyboard or into the pen. Where the reality of alienation and gravity of oppression sinks itself into my words. It's one of the only mediums in which I can have a dialogue with my blood and my history primordially. Within the last three years, my family and I have lost six of our loved ones, nearly all were tragic. Most recently COVID-19 took the lives of my Grandpa and Uncle Jose. At 20 years old, meditating with mourning and melancholia has never felt more valuable. From an even larger picture, between viruses and bureaucratic brutality, it feels as if grief is an inescapable truth of black consciousness. A truth which has touched my life deeply in the these last quick years of youth. Although, within my infatuation with death I find an undaunting certainty at the end of my imagination. My writing allows me to weave and work through these issues as new traumas present themselves to me through technology, grief, and time.
